docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation would have a claim to one-third of the profits earned by the flagship energy trading business that it plans to sell to UBS Warburg, the investment firm, executives at the firm said yesterday. The money would start to flow no later than the end of the year. Contrary to initial expectations, Enron will not have an equity stake in the unit once it is sold. The deal is expected to be structured to give UBS an incentive to buy Enron's interest in the new entity's profits after five years; otherwise, the royalty payments would increase to 45 percent of profits from 33 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN folks in Washington march into a mess to fix it, their solutions are, alas, usually worse than the problem ever was. Nevertheless, it is gratifying that the subject of excess risk lurking in workers' 401(k) plans is finally front and center with lawmakers. The new focus on a not-new problem stems, of course, from the Enron smash-up, in which many of the company's workers could only watch as their retirement plans -- stuffed with Enron stock -- sank like a stone as the company spiraled into bankruptcy. Most egregiously, workers were prevented from selling their Enron shares for several weeks last fall when the administrator of the plan was being changed; they were trapped and their fortunes plunged. Enron executives, meanwhile, were dumping their shares before the unraveling.
docs.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column says employees increase their risk by having major part of their 401(k) retirement plan invested in their own company's stock; cites Enron Corp's example as well as analysis performed by RiskMetrics; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation and Enel S.p.A., Italy's state electricity utility, said yesterday that they would form a 5 trillion lire ($2.9 billion) power-generating venture to take advantage of opportunities in Europe's electricity market. As part of the agreement, Enel would contribute about 10 power plants and Enron, the Houston-based energy company, would pay to upgrade and expand them. The new company would be able to generate as much as 5,000 megawatts of power. Shares of Enron rose 50 cents yesterday, to $40.50.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Labor Department is expected to sue about 20 officials of the Enron Corporation and its retirement plans today, arguing that they breached their fiduciary duty to protect Enron employees from the huge losses they incurred when the company's stock price collapsed. A person who has seen a copy of the complaint said the lawsuit would seek to recover the money Enron's employees lost when the company collapsed, depleting their retirement accounts. Civil lawsuits that have already been filed say the workers lost more than $1 billion in total.

docs.lead_paragraph: Electricity traders at Enron drove up prices during the California power crisis through questionable techniques that company lawyers said ''may have contributed'' to severe power shortages, according to internal Enron documents released today by federal regulators. Within Enron, the documents show, traders used strategies code-named Fat Boy, Ricochet, Get Shorty, Load Shift and Death Star to increase Enron's profits from trading power in the state -- techniques that added to electricity costs and congestion on transmission lines.
docs.abstract: Internal Enron documents released by federal regulators show company's electricity traders drove up prices during California power crisis through questionable techniques that company lawyers say may have contributed to severe power shortages; show traders used strategies to increase company profits that added to electricity costs and congestion on transmission lines; other findings discussed; US Sen Dianne Feinstein will ask Justice Dept to pursue criminal probe to determine whether federal fraud statutes or any other laws were violated; memos are strong evidence for state officials, who have long argued that Enron and other power marketers manipulated state's market and played crucial role in crisis that cost California consumers and utilities tens of billions of dollars in 2000 and 2001; photo (M)
